lead_paragraph: A computer science student in a former Soviet republic found there was money to be made in mixing real and made-up stories, as long as they were pro-Trump.

byline.contributor: Andrew Higgins reported from Tbilisi, Georgia, and Mike McIntire and Gabriel J.X. Dance from New York.
byline.original: By ANDREW HIGGINS, MIKE McINTIRE and GABRIEL J.X. DANCE

headline.print_headline: Websites Hit a ‘Gold Mine’ in Fake News
headline.main: Inside a Fake News Sausage Factory: ‘This Is All About Income’

snippet: A computer science student in a former Soviet republic found there was money to be made in mixing real and made-up stories, as long as they were pro-Trump....
abstract: Websites run by student Beqa Latsabidze of Georgian Republic and Canadian satirist John Egan offer insight into ecosystem of fake news, on Internet and social media, which Pres Obama has warned may be corrosive threat; sites were started without any partisan goal, yet they proved to be extremely lucrative for their owners during 2016 presidential election.
